data.title: False positive errors highlighted

data.title: Make --extensionHomePath consistent casing with the rest of the command line args
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.6.0-insider (50bb7aad57cbf1924e28472de52734be49645558, 2016-09-15T05:58:53.508Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-31-generic, Ubuntu 16.04

Can we change it to `--extension-home-dir <dir>` or `--extension-dir <dir>` to match `--user-data-dir <dir>`?

```
❯ c --help
Visual Studio Code - Insiders 1.6.0-insider

Usage: code-insiders [options] [paths...]

Options:
  -d, --diff                  Open a diff editor. Requires to pass two file
                              paths as arguments.
  --disable-extensions        Disable all installed extensions.
  -g, --goto                  Open the file at path at the line and column (add
                              :line[:column] to path).
  --locale <locale>           The locale to use (e.g. en-US or zh-TW).
  -n, --new-window            Force a new instance of Code.
  -p, --performance           Start with the 'Developer: Startup Performance'
                              command enabled.
  -r, --reuse-window          Force opening a file or folder in the last active
                              window.
  --user-data-dir <dir>       Specifies the directory that user data is kept
                              in, useful when running as root.
  --verbose                   Print verbose output (implies --wait).
  -w, --wait                  Wait for the window to be closed before
                              returning.
  --extensionHomePath         Set the root path for extensions.
  --list-extensions           List the installed extensions.
  --install-extension <ext>   Installs an extension.
  --uninstall-extension <ext> Uninstalls an extension.
  -v, --version               Print version.
  -h, --help                  Print usage.
```

data.title: Suggestion: Add keybinding to "Switch to next input point"
data.body: Just like writing HTML in Sublime using Emmet to generate tags and switch cursor to next input area with `Ctrl` + `Alt` + `→`

data.title: gutterIconPath is not loading correctly in Insider release
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.0 Insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Define a `pathIcon` variable using `context.asAbsolutePath('images\\bookmark.png')` 

``` typescript
let pathIcon: string = context.asAbsolutePath('images\\bookmark.png');
```
1. Create a decorator and use the `pathIcon` variable as `gutterIconPath`.

``` typescript
let bookmarkDecorationType = vscode.window.createTextEditorDecorationType({
        gutterIconPath: pathIcon,
        overviewRulerLane: vscode.OverviewRulerLane.Full,
        overviewRulerColor: 'rgba(21, 126, 251, 0.7)'
    });
```
1. The image will not be loaded, and it will output an error in `Developer Tools` console

```
GET file:///C:/%5CUsers%5Calefr%5C.vscode-insiders%5Cextensions%5Calefragnani.Bookmarks-0.9.1%5Cimages%5Cbookmark.png net::ERR_FILE_NOT_FOUND
```

Unfortunattely, I'm also not able to debug in Insider release ([this issue](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/12078)). Maybe something in `gutterIconPath` or `Uri` has changed and now the file is not being located?

Thanks in advance

data.title: Automatically remove trailing /** from file exclusion patterns
data.body: Exclusion patterns like **/node_modules/** don't benefit from the 'find' optimizations as the equivalents without trailing /*\* like **/node_modules do. (Extracted from #11963.)

data.title: Add setting editor.scrollCursorWithLine

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/1051 mentioned this setting. Where did it go?

---

Additionally, the setting "editor.scrollCursorWithLine" was added (defaults to false). When set to true, the caret will be moved up/down along with scrolling. This feature makes it possible for the user to scroll in a document by using keyboard shortcuts while keeping the same number of visible lines before and after the cursor.

data.title: Fixes #12063: Enable "Open with Code" on drives but not recycle bin
data.body:
Fixes #12063.
This is a complement to #11870.
Removed the "Folder" registry keys, restored the "directory" ones and added the "Drive" ones.

data.title: VS Code does render all UTF8 characters correctly
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Windows Server 2016 RS1, Windows 10 AU

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Copy these characters `ᚠᛇᚻᚠᛇᚻ` into any Visual Studio Code file.

These are the Rune characters from http://www.columbia.edu/~fdc/utf8/
1. In Visual Studio Code they will appear as blank rectangles, however if you paste them into Notepad they render correctly.

I tried Consolas, Courier New and monospaced and they all would not render the characters correctly.

![utf8](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5819622/18569446/76df6bf6-7b57-11e6-9076-64386e9aed00.png)

data.title: Improve C/C++ colorizer
data.body:
The status quo:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/240091/18569129/5ead3190-7bd3-11e6-8eaf-91b91d869868.png)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/240091/18569133/6204f8aa-7bd3-11e6-8059-ff2874ab9374.png)

The problem:
- No special color for operators.
- No special color for user-defined types, like `caryll_buffer`.
- Pointers and references should be colored.

data.title: Allow "Find All References" to expand to a full tab
data.body:
Right now "find all references" opens the code-lens pop-up. If I am in a large project and want to see all references to a symbol such as an interface, I might want to bounce between different implementations. This is made difficult by the fact that the list of references doesn't persist/can't be expanded.

It would be great if there was an option to expand the "find all references" results into the search tab, and navigate between them. Bad mspaint mockup below, with the references listed on the right and the referencing code in a tab on the right.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2957173/18567386/2e37ccc2-7b98-11e6-9a8e-fe93752e24b7.png)

data.title: Test HTML/Razor/Handlebar
data.body:
- [x] Linux @bpasero 
- [x] MacOS @sandy081
- [x] Win @bgashler1 

Complexity 3

The HTML language has been refactored from a legacy mode to an extension. Syntax highlighting is now using TextMate grammars.

Test for all 3 languages (HTML, Razor, Handlebar)
- syntax highlighting. Note: For Razor to highlight embedded C# code, a C# extension must be installed.
- Commenting, bracket matching, indentation after brackets, autoClosingPairs, Surround with brackets. See [html/language-configuration.json](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/html/language-configuration.json) for the brackets/comments to expect
- Code assist for html tags, attributes and values.
  - Type '<' to see tag proposals
  - verify that '</' will propose to close the most inner element
  - verify that picking a '</' proposal will fix the indent
  - test that in html you see also angular and ionic proposals and that you can disable them with the settings
- Highlighting of open and close tags
- That link detection for `src` and `href` works and that the links are correctly followed.
- Test HTML formatting. Also test that changing the formatter settings has an effect. Note: we use http://jsbeautifier.org/ as formatter. Use that page to compare.

data.title: Rename Symbol doesn't catch all occurrences of the symbol
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.5.2 (66f37fd2a99eb9d628dd374d81d78835b410c39b, 2016-09-12T13:30:03.456Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
  ``
  Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create foo.py with the following content:

```
def foo():
    x = 123
    if x:
        return str(x)
    return None
```
1. Using F2 or via right click Rename Symbol menu option, rename **x** to **y**
2. At this point, the first two occurrences of **x** are renamed to **y** but **str(x)** remains unchanged
3. Note: it seems parentheses relate to the issue.  Returning just **x** renames correctly.  The problem still occurs when using some other **bar** rather than **str**.

data.title: Prompt user for opening all tabs for replace all
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

Currently, if someone is doing a project-wise replace, VSCode opens all modified files after the change.

If 100 files are changed, VSCode opens 100 tabs. Should prompt user.

data.title: Use Git rather than GitHub icon for Git-related files in default icon set
data.body:
Love the new file icons feature, but have one minor issue: Git-related file types are mapped to the GitHub icon:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/341507/18561439/b78bc546-7b34-11e6-8b90-ebef9707d432.png)

This can be seen in extensions/theme-seti/icons/vs-seti-icon-theme.json:

``` json
"gitignore": "_github",  
"gitkeep": "_github",  
"gitattributes": "_github",
```

A little nitpicky, I know, but Git != GitHub. A Git icon ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/341507/18561363/5d115f4a-7b34-11e6-8099-1e1dc1a01f9b.png) (also available in Seti) would be more appropriate.

data.title: Formatting jsx file adds and removes meaningful spaces
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2 - OS Version: Windows 7 SP1 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open .jsx file ``` import React from 'react' class Sample extends React.Component { render() { return (
Joe's Text
Joe. Text.
) } } export default Sample ``` 1. Run formatting `Joe's Text` changes to `Joe' s Text` (space is added), `Joe. Text.` changes to `Joe.Text.` (space is removed)

data.title: Inform the user that VS Code ships TS 2.0
data.body:
TypeScript 2.0 is a major release and we should not just silently update to this version:
- [x] remove the existing guidance for how to use 2.0
- [x] add a one time message when opening a TS or JS file that TS 2.0 is included with a link to the 2.0 release notes
- [x] in the release notes mention how to stay on 1.8 using the tsdk options.

data.title: Implement VSIX drag and drop to extension viewlet

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.title: Ability to disable commit message length warning.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. In the Git panel/tab, enter a commit message which is longer than 50 characters.
2. Note that a warning is displayed.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4859660/18557943/f864b974-7b3e-11e6-9e5f-ec6fecf4b8c3.png)

I find this warning to be a bit controlling, and would like to disable it. The opinion that a commit message should be < 50 characters may not work for every user, or every team.
